User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 5.1; rv:7.0a2) Gecko/20110813 Firefox/7.0a2
Build ID: 20110813042013

Steps to reproduce:

Visit http://www.vortez.net/articles_pages/msi_870a_fuzion_power_edition_motherboard_review,1.html and scroll to the bottom of the Page. There you will find a Menu that you can click on to jump to a specific Page (refer to first attached Image).


Actual results:

If you position the Page as shown in the 1st enclosed Image you can see that the Web Page pops up a Menu that extends OUTSIDE the Browser's Chrome.

In the second Image I moved the Browser's Window close to the bottom of my Screen. When the Menu pops up and it would result in it leaving the Screen area the Broswer (correctly) it 'opens upward' and thus does not extend outside the Chrome.



Expected results:

I suggest that the second Image is correct in EITHER case and that Browser Elements should not pop out of the Chrome. If it (the popup) were carefully constructed it could lead the User to believe that the popup was on the Desktop and have a message insisting that you click [OK] or [CANCEL], etc. ...

BTW: IE and Google Chrome have the same Bug.

2. Click on the 'Menu Page Selector' (labeled "Introduction").

On this Page http://www.hardwarecanucks.com/forum/hardware-canucks-reviews/58566-intel-dc-s3700-200gb-800gb-enterprise-ssd-review.html it actually escapes not only the Browser's Window but goes as far as to obscure the OS's Taskbar (that is CLEARLY off limits).


Even more odd is this behaviour: 

1. Grab the Bowser's Window (top Chrome, left click) and move the Browser's Window downward so that the Toolbar (on the bottom of the Browser's Window) is completely UNDER the OS's Taskbar.
2. Now click on the Webpage's Menu.
3. See it open upward as it should have (when it ought to have checked IF it would have escaped the Browser's Window).

AND

4. Grab the Bowser's Window again and move the Browser's Window SLIGHTLY UPward so that the Toolbar is at least partly visible and not completely obscured by the OS's Taskbar.
5. Now click on the Webpage's Menu.
6. See it open DOWNward. The Program no longer checks IF it would have escaped the Browser's Window and prceeds to obscure the OS's Taskbar.


The TRUE size of the Browser's Window is not being correctly calculated and the Webpage's renderings are not being restricted to the confines of the Browser's Chrome.

comments.author: rob1weld@gmail.com
comments.creator: rob1weld@gmail.com
comments.text:
It can go outside of the Browser's Chrome (area assigned on the Screen by the Operating System), and it can even extend itself over the Operating System's Toolbar (clearly out of bounds).

It would seem to me that as a minimum it "looks improper", a stronger view may well be that it violates the Operating System; either way it is enough to be "a Bug" (tell us why it is not please).


Thanks.
